entry.title: Lebanon money exchangers back at work after strike

media:group.media:title: Lebanon money exchangers back at work after strike
media:group.media:description:
Money exchangers in Lebanon have ended their strike and returned to work. The government had blamed them for the devaluation of the local currency. There now appears to be a deal to control the currency market. But many warn that stabilising the exchange rate cannot happen as long as US dollars are in short supply Al Jazeera's Zeina Khodr reports.

entry.title: Landslides kill at least 20 in India's Assam state

media:group.media:title: Landslides kill at least 20 in India's Assam state
media:group.media:description:
At least 20 people - including children - have died in landslides in India's northeast Assam state. After days of heavy rain, several makeshift homes gave way on Tuesday morning. The community is now bracing for even more rain in the coming days. Al Jazeera's Katia Lopez Hoda-Yan has more.

#AlJazeeraEnglish #India

entry.title: Will US protests lead to political change? I Inside Story

media:group.media:title: Will US protests lead to political change? I Inside Story
media:group.media:description:
The killing of George Floyd has reignited pent up anger towards racism and police brutality in the United States. Since his death in Minneapolis more than a week ago, there have been nationwide, mainly peaceful protests. People defied curfews in more than 140 cities to demand justice for Floyd and other black Americans who've died at the hands of police. But President Donald Trump has threatened to shoot looters and send in the army. Presumptive Democratic nominee, former Vice President Joe Biden, says Trump is making the country even more divided. So, is there enough momentum to change laws and attitudes in a polarised election year?
Presenter: Bernard Smith
Guests:
Jason Nichols - Progressive Political and Social Analyst.
Rosa Clemente - Community Organizer.
Richard Goodstein - Democratic Political Strategist.
- Subscribe to our channel: http://aje.io/AJSubscribe - Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/
#AlJazeeraEnglish #BlackLivesMatter #US #InsideStory

entry.title: AP investigation: China withheld COVID-19 information

media:group.media:title: AP investigation: China withheld COVID-19 information
media:group.media:description:
China withheld vital information about the outbreak and waited more than a week before publishing the genome of the novel coronavirus in January. That is according to an investigation by The Associated Press news agency, which found that the World Health Organization officials heaped praise on Beijing to coax more information. Al Jazeera's Katrina Yu reports from Beijing, China.
- Subscribe to our channel: http://aje.io/AJSubscribe - Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/
#AlJazeeraEnglish #Coronavirus #China

entry.title: Can the Navajo Nation survive coronavirus? | The Stream

media:group.media:title: Can the Navajo Nation survive coronavirus? | The Stream
media:group.media:description:
Native American communities are so disproportionately affected by the coronavirus that the Navajo Nation, the largest reservation in the US, has a higher per-capita infection rate than any state in the nation.
This week the tribe’s death toll reached at least 241 with as many as 5,250 people testing positive.
Stemming the tide has proven a monumental task given years of federal government neglect, a lack of running water, high rates of chronic illness and an ageing population. In an attempt to stop the spread of the virus, tribal leaders have instituted as many as seven weekend lockdowns during which nobody was permitted to leave or enter the reservation.
Despite the challenges, younger people have stepped up and played a pivotal role in their community’s grassroots response. Many feel it’s on their shoulders to protect their elders lives and ensure their traditions are passed down.
In this episode of the Stream we meet people from the Navajo Nation and ask why they are so disproportionately affected and what can be done to turn the tide. Join the conversation: TWITTER: https://twitter.com/AJStream FACEBOOK: http://www.facebook.com/AJStream Subscribe to our channel http://bit.ly/AJSubscribe
#aljazeeraenglish #ajstream #navajo

entry.title: Sudan: One year since crackdown government yet to deliver justice

media:group.media:title: Sudan: One year since crackdown government yet to deliver justice
media:group.media:description:
Sudanese authorities have put up barricades outside the military headquarters to stop protesters from gathering there. Crowds are expected to mark a year since a violent crackdown by security forces in which more than 100 people were killed and 700 others wounded. The uprising saw President Omar al-Bashir removed from power. But many victims say those who replaced him are yet to deliver justice.
Al Jazeera’s Hiba Morgan reports from Khartoum.

#AlJazeeraEnglish #Sudan

entry.title: Life-saving medical equipment patrols Sweden skies

media:group.media:title: Life-saving medical equipment patrols Sweden skies
media:group.media:description:
While the world remains focused on COVID-19, the disease caused by the novel coronavirus, a more deadly illness remains a largely hidden statistic. More than 17 million people die of cardiovascular disease every year. And as Al Jazeera's Paul Rhys reports from Gothenburg in Sweden, a new life-saving solution is patrolling the skies.

#AlJazeeraEnglish #Sweden

entry.title: Colombia: Bogota keeping coronavirus lockdown measures

media:group.media:title: Colombia: Bogota keeping coronavirus lockdown measures
media:group.media:description:
Coronavirus lockdown measures are being lifted across Colombia, with the exceptions of the capital, Bogota, and two other hard-hit cities.
The mayor of Bogota has reimposed a total lockdown in a working-class area of more than a million people, which has become the new epicentre of the outbreak.
Al Jazeera's Alessandro Rampietti reports from Bogota.
- Subscribe to our channel: http://aje.io/AJSubscribe - Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/
#AlJazeeraEnglish #Colombia #Coronavirus

entry.title: Afghanistan: Civilian Loss in the US Air War | Fault Lines

media:group.media:title: Afghanistan: Civilian Loss in the US Air War | Fault Lines
media:group.media:description:
As the United States has increased its use of airstrikes in the war in Afghanistan, it’s come with a heavy price as civilian casualties from airstrikes have reached record numbers.
In “Afghanistan: Civilian Loss in the US Air War,” Fault Lines reports on what justice looks like for civilians who lost loved ones to airstrikes.
The US military has a poor record of investigating civilian casualty allegations from airstrikes, leaving few options for civilians looking for justice when they lose family members and leading to a lack of accountability for these deaths.
As the US prepares for the possibility of leaving Afghanistan after nearly 20 years, Fault Lines asks how civilian loss is investigated and remembered.
- Subscribe to our channel: http://aje.io/AJSubscribe - Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/

entry.title: US mobile testing: Minorities have a harder time getting tested

media:group.media:title: US mobile testing: Minorities have a harder time getting tested
media:group.media:description:
COVID-19 is disproportionately killing African Americans.
To make matters worse, testing for the virus is scarce in poor, largely minority communities hit hardest by the virus.
But one doctor in New Jersey is working to address that issue.
Dr Alexander Salerno is offering mobile testing for COVID-19 infections from the back of his van.
Al Jazeera’s Gabriel Elizondo report from the US state of New Jersey.
- Subscribe to our channel: http://aje.io/AJSubscribe - Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/
#AlJazeeraEnglish #Coronavirus #UnitedStates

entry.title: Through tears, mother of George Floyd's daughter demands justice

media:group.media:title: Through tears, mother of George Floyd's daughter demands justice
media:group.media:description:
Roxie Washington says Floyd was a good man and father. The mother of George Floyd’s daughter held an emotional news conference as the state of Minnesota began an investigation into racism within the Minneapolis Police Department. There has been another night of protest and anger in cities across the United States as crowds defied curfews to march against racism and police brutality.
Al Jazeera’s John Hendren reports from Minneapolis in the US state of Minnesota.
- Subscribe to our channel: http://aje.io/AJSubscribe - Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/
#JusticeForGeorgeFlyod #GeorgeFloyd #GeorgeFloydprotest

entry.title: Experts say Latin America coronavirus death toll under-reported

media:group.media:title: Experts say Latin America coronavirus death toll under-reported
media:group.media:description:
There are now more than a million cases of COVID-19 across Latin America. Brazil, Peru and Chile have been the worst hit, with many lower-income people forced to go out seeking work, ignoring physical distancing and stay-at-home orders. A new study takes a second look at the official death tolls, concluding that they have been significantly under-reported, with real numbers possible triple the official count.
Al Jazeera’s Lucia Newman reports from Santiago, Chile.
- Subscribe to our channel: http://aje.io/AJSubscribe - Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/
#Coronavirus #Covid19 #LatinAmerica

entry.title: Floyd protesters continue to rally as Trump decries 'lowlifes'

media:group.media:title: Floyd protesters continue to rally as Trump decries 'lowlifes'
media:group.media:description:
The United States has been gripped by protests over the death of George Floyd - an unarmed Black man who died last week in police custody in Minneapolis, Minnesota - and police brutality nationwide. US President Donald Trump has outraged faith leaders and protesters for walking to a historic church near the White House and creating a photo opportunity, just minutes after police used chemical smoke canisters and flashbangs on peaceful protesters to clear the way for the rare walk.
Al Jazeera’s Mike Hanna reports from the US capital, Washington, DC.
- Subscribe to our channel: http://aje.io/AJSubscribe - Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/
#Trump #GeorgeFloyd #GeorgeFloydprotest

entry.title: Lessons from lockdown: Cities to share experiences with COVID-19

media:group.media:title: Lessons from lockdown: Cities to share experiences with COVID-19
media:group.media:description:
As coronavirus restrictions begin lifting around the world, many countries are looking abroad, to understand the different responses to the pandemic. While some countries shut down immediately, others had a more relaxed approach. Now, mayors from 40 cities around the world are sharing their experiences via a teleconference hosted by the South Korean capital, Seoul.
Al Jazeera’s Rob McBride reports from Seoul, South Korea.
- Subscribe to our channel: http://aje.io/AJSubscribe - Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/
#Coronavirus #CAC2020 #SouthKorea

entry.title: Brazil anti-racism rallies: Protesters blame Bolsonaro

media:group.media:title: Brazil anti-racism rallies: Protesters blame Bolsonaro
media:group.media:description:
Anti-racism demonstrations are being held in Brazil, where around half the population is Black or mixed race. The protesters blame President Jair Bolsonaro for the growing discrimination.
Al Jazeera's Teresa Bo reports.
- Subscribe to our channel: http://aje.io/AJSubscribe - Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/
